ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Multivariable calculus. While intuition was stressed, problems were computational.
I learned about multivariable calculus and problem-solving. I learned more about how to visualize problems.
Knowledge of double integrals, multiple variables
I learned more about integrals.
Multivariable calculus.
Multivariable calculus
Basic understanding of multivariate calculus- from vectors to flux to triple integrals. The course basically teaches general Stokes' theorem, despite not naming it expressly.
a lot of math that's probably useful in a lot of fields (lagrange optimization for econ maybe, flux integrals for electric fields in physics, etc.)
Learned all the important information on 3D space/calculus.
An understanding of how calculus can be applied to real life situations - helped me develop an interest towards applied math
I learned many topics included within a multivariable calculus class such as double and triple integrals, Green's theorem, Stokes' Theorem, parameterizations of lines and surfaces, etc.
Visualizing and understanding 3D space. I learned how to approach a problem in different ways through establishing logical methods given the known information of the problem.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Personally, I really like calculus, but some may see this class as a necessary evil. If you enjoy doing a lot of (sometimes tedious) calculations, it can be a strength, but often the practice problems seem more like busywork than emphasizing learning.
I wished this course didn't have so much self-study and self-preparation.
Honestly very well taught. Im not a huge math guy but the videos and sudesh were awesome
I enjoyed the break out rooms. Sometimes, the pre-recorded videos were confusing.

Strengths: structure was clear and an effort was made to synthesize material across the course, a weakness perhaps was that the preparation for class and the lectures repeated each other quite a lot, using time that could have been spent on more examples or deeper explanations.
Excellent

Sudesh is a really really really good teacher, but I think Zoom really hurt this course. I had a very hard time visualizing what we were talking about, and seeing it described on a white page over Zoom did not help. Sudesh did a really good job of linking geogebra lessons, using props, and being available for office hours, but math over Zoom is not my strong suit.

This course was extremely organized and we always knew what to expect on the tests and there was ample opportunities to learn and review material. Even though there is a 20/25/30 grading structure, one had to basically perfect to do well so it's pretty stressful throughout the semester as grading is pretty harsh. But overall the course as bad as I thought it would be.

The strength of this course was 100% my prof Sudesh. That man is a legend and I can't recommend this class highly enough if you get in his section. Weakness: online interactions were a bit dull/awkward in class.
I felt that the course covered too many topics too quickly.

Strengths: Curriculum seems well-thought-out, professor was great (at least mine was), problem sets are good prep for exams

Weaknesses: Not really I can think of - it is a math course with 3 midterms and weekly problem sets. I got exactly what I expected.

The lectures and notes were clear. The professor provided a lot of opportunities to ask questions. 

One thing that may be improved are the pre-class quizzes. It feels as though they take up too much time (taking time away from solving the problem sets) - if the pre-class quizzes provided more direction as to what we should specifically focus on and the questions tested the fundamental knowledge needed to go into the next class prepared (as opposed to a trick question), it may be better.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the breakout rooms we had when working on group problems. The use of Notability and screen sharing was also very helpful.
If there can be in person classes, do it
I liked that our classes were recorded.
Sort of invasive testing practices

Anything which allows you to practice the material outside of graded quizzes or homework help. So often, we would miss one detail due to Zoom fatigue and then be unable to orient a surface. Just getting low stress practice is the best way to solve these minor lapses.

My professor, the man the myth the legend Sudesh, really tried to check in to make sure we understood the concepts throughout the virtual lecture, had plenty of office hours and had polls throughout the virtual lecture to keep us engaged.
There were recorded lectures but my prof uploaded the class notes and was very organized so they weren't that necessary.

The polls during class allowed for students to stay engaged which was beneficial. 

The pre-class quizzes took too much time away from completing the problem sets - I believe it would be beneficial if these were shortened a bit.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Even if you don't need it for your major but like math, I would recommend this class.
Yes if you need it for your major or if you really like calculus.
Yes, if you could have sudesh
I would recommend this course if the student likes math.
Yes if you are interested in mathematics or need it for a major, otherwise no.
With Sudesh, YES!
Yes- but you need to like math. Unless you are doing select STEM things, this course is no super applicable to the real world. If you are doing those STEM things, you will have to take this anyway.
Sure? I kinda needed it for higher level econ courses, but also didn't really and it was alright. If you have Sudesh, you're literally fine. It's hard, you will have to put work in, but it's doable.
I would recommend if you get Sudesh as your professor, he was possibly the best teacher I've ever had when it comes to explaining concepts in a clear and interesting way.
Yes. It seems to be a crucial course for most STEM related majors.
I would recommend this course to another student. I think it was well taught and I learned a lot from it. This course is also a prerequisite for many STEM majors.

Yes, I would recommend if you want to analyze and work with 3D spaces in a rigorous setting. This class is not easy and takes a lot of effort, but the material is interesting and pushes your understanding.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Class sessions were recorded.
Pre class videos
Virtual office hours
Office hours
virtual lecture + recorded videos
There were weekly videos and small quizzes to introduce the topics of that week which I thought were helpful, but could sometimes be a bit much.
Recorded lecture.
